metadata.case_name: Appellants (Ex-proprietors) v. Gendalal Motilal Patni & Ors.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950 was passed.

Appellants applied under s.19(1) of the Act for determination of their debts, specifying secured debts including mortgage debt of respondent No.1 Gendalal Motilal Patni which resulted in decree for Rs. 2,16,309.
Patni objected under s.21 that the debt ceased to be secured for purposes of s.17(a) of the Act.
Claims Officer overruled Patni's objection on November 19, 1951, holding debt remained secured and recoverable on vesting date, and called upon Patni to file statement under s.22.
Patni appealed to Madhya Pradesh Board of Revenue instead of filing statement.
Board of Revenue on June 15, 1954 held Claims Officer had no jurisdiction to determine character of debt, following Ramkrishna v. Board of Revenue (A.T.R. 1954 Nag. 248).
Patni moved Civil Court which decided the debt was secured for purposes of Abolition Act.
Patni filed statement of claim before Claims Officer on January 23, 1958.
Appellants objected that statement was out of time and claim should be discharged.
Claims Officer accepted objection and discharged claim on December 24, 1962.
Patni appealed to Commissioner, Nagpur Division (Rev. Appeal No. 2/57/62/63).
Commissioner on May 5, 1964 set aside Claims Officer's order, noting earlier Nagpur HC decision overruled by A.I.R. 1956 Nag. 193, revived 1951 order, remanded for disposal under s.22(1).
Appellants filed Special Civil Application No. 471 of 1964 under Arts. 226/227 in Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench challenging Commissioner's jurisdiction.
High Court summarily dismissed petition on September 21, 1964.
Appellants applied for certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) or (c) in Misc. Application No. 13 of 1965.
High Court refused certificate on February 1, 1965.
Special Leave Petition (Civil) No. 395 of 1965 filed against main High Court order of Sep 21, 1964, kept pending sine die by SC order dated July 30, 1965.
Amount/value of subject matter exceeds Rs. 20,000.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellants entitled to certificate as of right under Art. 133(1)(a) or (b) against High Court's refusal in proceedings under Art. 226/227.
Whether proceedings under Art. 226 are 'civil proceedings' under Art. 133.
Whether summary dismissal order under Art. 226 is a 'judgment, decree or final order' under Art. 133.
Whether Art. 133 applies to extraordinary original jurisdiction under Art. 226 or only appellate/ordinary original jurisdiction.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appeal lay as of right to Supreme Court and certificate wrongly refused by High Court.
Commissioner had no jurisdiction to entertain appeal and set aside Claims Officer's discharge order.

respondent_arguments.text: Art. 133(1) gives right of appeal only against judgments/decrees/final orders in appellate or ordinary original civil jurisdiction, not extraordinary original under Art. 226.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 133; ss.109, 110 CPC; Municipal Officer, Aden v. Abdul Karim

respondent_arguments.text: Order dismissing Art. 226 petition summarily is not a judgment, decree or final order as it decides nothing on merits and does not finally affect rights.
Proceeding under Art. 226 is not a civil proceeding.

court_reasoning.text: Proceedings before revenue authorities and High Court under Art. 226 concern civil rights of parties and are civil proceedings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Civil proceeding includes all proceedings affecting civil rights which are not criminal.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 133 uses 'any judgment, decree or final order in a civil proceeding' without limiting to appellate/ordinary original jurisdiction; covers extraordinary jurisdiction under Art. 226.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words are as wide as language can make them to cover new jurisdictions.

court_reasoning.text: In Art. 226 proceedings, High Court decides independently whether to quash inferior tribunal's decision; dismissal is final as to that controversy (jurisdiction challenge).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finality attaches to the special proceeding before High Court, not underlying controversy.

court_reasoning.text: High Court upheld Commissioner's jurisdiction by dismissing petition; order final for Art. 133 purposes; amount exceeds Rs.20,000 attracting cl.(a) and (b).
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred in refusing certificate.

holdings.text: Art. 226 proceedings affecting civil rights are civil proceedings under Art. 133.
Summary dismissal of Art. 226 petition challenging jurisdiction is final order under Art. 133.
Art. 133 applies to extraordinary original jurisdiction under Art. 226.
Appellants entitled to certificate under Art. 133(1)(a)/(b); High Court order refusing certificate set aside.

precedents_cited.relevance: Board of Revenue followed it to hold Claims Officer no jurisdiction; later overruled.
Overruled earlier decision; Claims Officer had jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. A. L. Narayan Row v. Ishwarlal Bhagwandas
precedents_cited.relevance: Civil proceedings include those affecting civil rights; wide interpretation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Municipal Officer, Aden v. Abdul Karim
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between jurisdictions under Letters Patent; not applicable to Art. 133's wide words.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs determination and discharge of proprietors' debts; jurisdiction of Claims Officer.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 133 for certificate/appeal in civil matters; Art. 226/227 for writs; Art. 132 for constitutional questions.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order dated February 1, 1965 refusing certificate under Art. 133 set aside; case remitted to High Court for disposal according to law. Civil Misc. Petition No. 2180 of 1965 dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Certificate deemed granted; underlying SLP to be heard after this appeal.
outcome.costs: First respondent to bear costs of appellant.

key_quotes.text: 'The term civil proceeding has been held in this Court to include, at least, all proceedings affecting civil rights, which are not criminal.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of 'civil proceeding' under Art. 133.

key_quotes.text: 'Article 133 not only discards the distinction between appellate and original jurisdictions but deliberately used words which are as wide as language can make them.'
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: 'A decision in the exercise of this jurisdiction... is a final decision in so far as the High Court is concerned because it terminates finally the special proceeding before it.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes finality of Art. 226 dismissal orders.
